timeline.bodyText: Why are you setting the image name to itself? and why do you have both a setter and a public property on Image? I'd rather than we just used getters and setters?
timeline.author: ashleyfrieze
ashleyfrieze

timeline.bodyText: Similar issue here with calling get when the findById may return empty.
timeline.author: ashleyfrieze

timeline.bodyText: Bad practice to use ordered tests - if a test case requires something from earlier, then it's probably one test case.
timeline.author: ashleyfrieze

replies.bodyText:
I find this topic discussable. I sure understand your point. But I see a trade-off here. If you consider that your tests should be as clean as possible, we should follow the Single Responsibility Principle. And asserting two different flows (save and find) is a clear violation of it.
Sure, if we create complex tests relying on order, it may become a mess. But the same is valid for huge test methods with many assertions.
With the order approach, we also have the benefit of a strict view of where is the problem, without depending on logs.
Anyway, I removed the ordering but kept both methods. Now the download test is relying on a mock. Kind of a middle ground.
As an integration test, I still see more ups than downs in ordering our tests. For these specific cases.
replies.author: GilvanOrnelas

timeline.author: ashleyfrieze

timeline.bodyText: You can see that this test is part of the other one as its given describes something that's not in its body.
timeline.author: ashleyfrieze

replies.bodyText:
From my point of view, the given is something expected for the test run as expected. Usually an argument, but it may be a pre-condition too.
Anyway, it is a little different now.
replies.author: GilvanOrnelas
ashleyfrieze

replies.bodyText:
Cool. I would love to see your "dependency JUnit tests".
TestNG has an interesting feature - dependsOnMethods. Defining dependencies is a little better than forcing an order. I wonder if your framework looks like it.
replies.author: GilvanOrnelas

timeline.bodyText: As a bonus, you could use BDDMockito.given rather than when. This is minor and optional. As you're expressing the given part of the test, it's awkward to be doing so using functions called when. That's a question of preference, though.
timeline.author: ashleyfrieze

replies.bodyText: I didn't know BDDMockito. A little more readable, same effort. Amazing! Thanks.
